awayTeam: Shrewsbury Cup Balance Tilts Toward Molineux Side But Trends Add Intrigue
previewParagraphs: Cup ties often hinge on who manages the key moments, and Wolverhampton host Shrewsbury with the numbers pointing one way while a few longer-term trends whisper caution. The visitors arrive struggling for goals, the hosts with a recent uptick, and both leaning into familiar shapes that could decide control in midfield.

Wolverhampton come in with a mixed last six in all competitions at 1 win, 2 draws and 3 losses, averaging 1.17 goals scored and 1.33 conceded. Their approach has been direct rather than possession heavy, with 9.17 shots per match, 4 on target and 39.67% possession across that span.

Shrewsbury’s last six read 0 wins, 2 draws and 4 losses in all competitions, a run built on a lean attack at 0.5 goals per match and 2.17 shots on target from 8.67 attempts. They have seen more of the ball than Wolves on average at 46.5% but have struggled to turn phases into clear chances.

These clubs have not crossed paths often, yet the most recent meeting at Molineux went the way of the hosts, with Wolverhampton winning the last home head to head. That edge matters in knockout football where small sample head to head moments can weigh on approach.

Shrewsbury’s broader cup record deserves mention. In the FA Cup specifically, they have won 60% of their last 15 matches, a useful counterbalance to their league and all-competitions form and a sign they can set up effectively for one-off ties.

At Molineux across the last three home matches in all competitions, Wolves are 1 win and 2 losses, scoring 1.33 and conceding 2.00 on average from 9.33 shots and 4 on target, with 37.67% possession. Shrewsbury’s last three overall yielded 0 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, 0.67 scored and 1.67 conceded. The top-line metrics tilt toward the hosts, especially in chance creation and conversion.

Wolves have a recent lift with a 3-match undefeated streak in all competitions, yet the long view warns they have been winless in 18 of their last 20 in all competitions and have lost 20 of their last 30. They have also lost by 2 or more in 6 of their last 15, and at home have fallen in 24 of their last 40, with 12 of their last 15 home matches ending winless. Even so, their shots on target at home hold around 4.35 per match.

Shrewsbury are winless in 16 of their last 20 in all competitions. They have drawn 50% of their last 8 and lost 50% of their last 14. Away from home the picture is harsh, with 63% of their last 40 away games ending in defeat, winless in 26 of their last 30 away, and 11 of those 30 away defeats by 2 or more. That travel profile is a key factor against higher-tier opposition.

Wolves have leaned on 3-5-2, using energy from the wingbacks and Hwang’s movement up front. Their numbers suggest quick transitions over long possessions, so the first pass into the front two and the surge from the half-spaces by Arias or Hugo Bueno could be decisive. Shrewsbury have alternated between 3-4-1-2 and 4-2-3-1, but the back three with a tucked playmaker suits containment and counters into Marquis and Lloyd.

previewParagraphs: Two sides built on structure and containment meet with plenty of familiar faces and even more familiar patterns. The numbers point to small details deciding it, and they keep circling back to a draw.

Everton’s last 6 in all competitions reads 1 win, 2 draws and 3 losses, with a modest 0.83 goals scored and 1.33 conceded per match. The chance creation profile is steady rather than overwhelming at 11.5 shots and 3.33 on target per game, alongside 40.33% average possession. At home across the last 3, they have 0 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, scoring 1.0 and conceding 2.0 per match with 10.67 shots, 3.0 on target and 41.67% possession.

Sunderland’s last 6 have produced 1 win, 4 draws and 1 loss, and an even leaner attack at 0.5 goals scored per match, balanced by a tidy 0.83 conceded. They average 9.67 shots, 3.33 on target and 44.17% possession. Away indicators are draw-heavy: 50% of their last 6 away games ended level, while they are winless in 9 of their last 11 away in all competitions.

The most recent meeting finished 1-1 on 2025-11-03, with Sunderland carrying more of the game. They posted 61% possession, led total shots 18 to 8 and edged shots on target 3 to 2. The pressure map told a similar story, with 62 dangerous attacks for Sunderland to Everton’s 28.

Iliman Ndiaye struck in the 15th minute to give the hosts the platform their control suggested. Everton were efficient rather than expansive and found their moment right after the interval, when Granit Xhaka equalized on 46 minutes. Despite territory and volume, Sunderland could not turn superiority into a winner, a theme that has bled into their broader run of draw-heavy results.

Everton’s broader picture in all competitions features variance at home. They have kept clean sheets in 42% of their last 12 home games, yet they have also lost by 2 or more in 43% of their last 7 home matches. Recent short-run form is shaky, with winless in 83% of their last 6, and their attack trending low volume to medium quality.

Sunderland have been hard to beat but equally hard to shake off their stalemate habits. They are undefeated in 16 of their last 20 in all competitions, yet winless in 10 of their last 12, underlining how often they share points. Away from home they have lost 4 of the last 8, and that 50% draw rate across the last 6 trips aligns with their scoring rate of 0.5 per game in the current 6-match slice.

Everton have won by 2 or more in 5 of their last 13 home matches, but also lost by 2 or more in 3 of their last 7 at home, a swingy profile that conflicts with Sunderland’s low-scoring lean. Head to head tilts slightly toward Everton’s punch: they have won by 2 or more in 2 of the last 3 meetings, even if the most recent clash finished 1-1. Sunderland’s draw gravity is pronounced with 10 draws in their last 20 in all competitions and winless in their last 5 overall, reinforcing a narrow-score expectation.

previewParagraphs: This FA Cup third-round tie brings together two sides with very different toolkits, yet both arrive with enough tells in their recent numbers to shape a clear blueprint. Cheltenham’s home sturdiness meets Leicester City’s higher gear in attack, and the balance between those forces could decide whether this becomes a statement night for the underdog or a routine step forward for the visitors.

Cheltenham enter with a workable platform. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions, Steve Cotterill’s side have produced 3 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, scoring 1.67 per game while conceding 1.5. The shot profile is healthy at 12.67 attempts and 3.67 on target per match, with an average 50% share of the ball that suggests they are comfortable mixing phases rather than chasing it.

At home, the sample tightens and the outlook improves. Across their last 3 at The EV Charger Points Stadium, Cheltenham have 2 wins and 1 loss, averaging 2.0 scored and 1.0 conceded. Shots remain steady at 12.0 per match, but accuracy climbs to 4.33 on target, a useful sign against opponents who can be opened up if you sustain pressure.

Trend-wise, Cheltenham have built consistency at home in all competitions. They haven’t been defeated in 8 of their last 10 home matches and have kept clean sheets in 40% of their last 15 at home. They have also won 8 of their last 15 home fixtures and posted 3 wins by 2 or more goals in their last 7 at home, underlining that when they get control, they can stretch a lead.

The Cup context is relevant too. In the FA Cup, Cheltenham have won 50% of their last 18 matches and lost 50% of their last 10. At home in this competition, they have taken 8 wins in their last 13, a reminder that their ground has hosted enough strong performances in knockout football to keep the tie live.

Leicester City arrive with punch but some variance. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions, Martí Cifuentes Corvillo’s team are 3 wins and 3 losses, scoring 1.67 and conceding 2.0. The shot count sits at 9.0 attempts with 2.5 on target and 47.33% possession on average, a profile that hints at moments of control rather than dominance, and a defense that can be asked questions.

The broader travel picture is a caution. In all competitions, Leicester are winless in 16 of their last 20 away matches and have lost 60% of their last 40 away games. They have also lost by 2 or more goals in 35% of those last 40 away trips. Countering that, they have still won 50% of their last 12 in all competitions, underscoring a capacity to spike performance on the right day.

Cheltenham’s approach likely leans on a compact 4-3-3, quick width and set-piece detail. With 12.67 shots per game and 3.67 on target, they create enough to matter if transitions are clean. Expect a measured press and an emphasis on early delivery from wide areas to test Leicester’s central pairing and full backs.

Leicester, typically aligned in a 4-2-3-1, will look to tilt the game through their wide creators and the central link. Issahaku Fatawu and Stephy Mavididi threaten directness, while Bobby De Cordova-Reid offers the connective tissue between midfield and the front. The key is raising shot volume beyond 9.0 attempts; if they do, their finishing quality can tell.

Coaching choices may be pivotal. Cotterill’s side have clear habits at home that limit chaos, while Cifuentes will want tempo and territory to keep Cheltenham’s midfield from settling. The first half-hour should reveal whether Leicester can pin Cheltenham back or whether the hosts can draw them into duels and free kicks in advanced zones.
Midfielders: Oliver Skipp, Jordan James, Issahaku Fatawu, Bobby De Cordova-Reid, Stephy Mavididi

previewParagraphs: With Serie A’s regular season pressing on, Udinese welcome AC Pisa to the Dacia Arena for a match that could prove decisive in shaping the destinies of both sides. Udinese are searching to solidify their mid-table status while AC Pisa desperately look for answers at the bottom of the standings.
These two sides last met on September 14, 2025, with Udinese traveling to AC Pisa and leaving with a narrow 1-0 victory.

The match was tightly contested, reflecting nearly even possession: Pisa recording 51% and Udinese 49%. Both teams had opportunities, with Pisa registering 12 total shots to Udinese’s 13, but only two were on target for the home side and three for Udinese.

The lone goal came early when Iker Bravo found the net in the 14th minute. Dangerous attacks, almost neck and neck at 41 for Pisa and 42 for Udinese, underlined the closeness of their tactical battle.
Udinese enter this fixture after a mixed sequence, collecting two wins, one draw, and three losses from their last six league outings.

They have averaged 1 goal per game while conceding 1.67, reflecting issues at both ends of the pitch. Their last three at home show a win, draw, and loss each, with marginal gains in shot creation and possession—averaging 18.67 shots and 47.33% possession.
AC Pisa endure a much bleaker run. Without a win in their last six matches, they have managed just two draws and four defeats, scoring only three times in that stretch while allowing ten goals.
Away from home, things are similarly grim, as they have failed to register a victory in 16 of their last 20 away games and have drawn three of their last six on the road.
Udinese stand 10th in the Serie A table from 19 fixtures, with a record reading seven wins, four draws, and eight defeats.

Their 20 goals for (1.05 per game) contrast with 30 conceded, resulting in a negative goal difference, a reminder of defensive frailties that occasionally mar their progress. AC Pisa, on the other hand, sit 20th with 1 win, 9 draws, and 9 losses from the same number of games played.
Their league-low 13 goals scored underline offensive woes, while conceding 28 times further exacerbates their predicament.
Udinese have tasted defeat in 7 of their last 12 across all competitions, yet have been more assured at home, winning 50% of their last six Serie A matches on familiar turf.
Defensively, losses by two or more goals account for 39% in their last 18, illustrating a susceptibility to being overrun at times.

AC Pisa’s woes are magnified by winless runs—failing to win in 19 of their last 20 matches in all competitions. However, five of their last six away matches have ended without defeat, indicating a tendency to be hard to break down on the road.

previewParagraphs: Union Berlin prepare to face Mainz at Stadion An der Alten Försterei with both sides seeking turning points for their Bundesliga campaigns. Union are looking to consolidate a midtable spot, while Mainz desperately need points to climb off the foot of the table. Both managers have crucial choices to make with personnel and tactics, and recent meetings suggest a competitive, tactical contest awaits.

Union Berlin’s recent run has been mixed. In their last six matches, they have won three and lost three, averaging 1.5 goals per game while conceding the same. Their performance at home has also been patchy, with just one win from the last three home matches and two defeats, scoring and conceding an average of two goals per match.

Mainz, on the other hand, continue to grapple with poor form. They have won only once in their last six, drawn three, and lost two, scoring an average of just 0.83 goals per game while conceding 1.33. Their away performances reflect broader problems, as they have failed to secure a win in 82% of their last 11 away matches in all competitions.

The head-to-head record offers little comfort for Mainz. Across the last 10 encounters, Union Berlin have emerged victorious six times, while Mainz have managed just a single win, with the remaining three ending in draws. Union’s dominance is further underlined by their overall edge across the last 20 meetings.
Looking more closely at Union’s recent home matches against Mainz, there’s a clear advantage: Union have won by a margin of two or more goals in 50% of the last six home encounters in this fixture.

Union hold 8th place after 15 matches, having won six, drawn three, and lost six, with a negative goal difference of minus three. They average 1.33 goals per game, but have conceded more often than they might like.

Mainz sit at the bottom in 18th with just one win all season from 15 games, five draws, and nine losses. Their struggle offensively is signaled by only 13 goals scored and a leaky defense, conceding 26. Their goal difference stands at minus 13.

Union’s last six matches in all competitions feature a perfectly balanced outcome—three wins and three losses, but their home form is showing signs of stress. Five of their last six home matches in all competitions have ended without victory. However, they have avoided defeat in five of their last six Bundesliga home games, suggesting a greater stubbornness on their own turf in league matches.

Mainz are currently winless in 13 of their last 16 matches across all competitions, and they have failed to win in 24 of their last 30 Bundesliga outings—sobering figures by any standard. The visitors have drawn 50% of their last eight Bundesliga games, but failing to convert draws into wins is costly. Notably, Mainz have not won any of their last 12 home matches in the Bundesliga but take a four-game undefeated streak in all competitions into this fixture, largely built on draws.

previewParagraphs: The Bundesliga clash at Millerntor-Stadion pits St Pauli against RB Leipzig in a fixture where form and firepower come sharply into focus. As the home side strive to lift themselves from the bottom half of the table, Leipzig arrive as clear favorites, boasting one of the league's most potent attacks.

St Pauli's record in their last two home encounters against RB Leipzig offers a glimmer of encouragement. Across these matches, St Pauli have managed one win and one draw, notably avoiding defeat and demonstrating resilience on their own turf. However, history outside these two games points strongly in Leipzig's favor, with the visitors winning two out of the last three meetings and both of those victories by a margin of two or more goals.

St Pauli approach this fixture with mixed recent results. In their last six matches, they've claimed two wins, drawn twice and lost two times, while averaging just one goal for and 1.17 conceded per match. Their offensive output at home has been slight, with an average of only 0.67 goals scored across the last three matches at Millerntor-Stadion, conceding two per game in the same period.

Leipzig, meanwhile, show signs of consistency and firepower. Over their previous six matches, they've taken three wins, a single draw, and two defeats, with an impressive average of 2.17 goals scored per outing and only 1.17 conceded. The visitors generate plenty of chances, leading with an average of 16.83 total shots and 7.33 on target per game in this span. Notably, their away form features five wins from their last ten on the road in all competitions.

St Pauli's league position underscores their uphill challenge. After 15 matches, they sit 16th, with just three wins, three draws, and nine defeats, struggling with a negative goal difference of -13 and an average of only 0.87 goals per game. Defensively, they've allowed 1.73 goals per match, underlining the issues at both ends.

Leipzig, on the other hand, are entrenched in the top four after 15 matches. They boast nine wins, two draws, and four losses, with a healthy goal return of 30 (an even two per game) and a positive goal differential of +11. Their defense allows just 1.27 goals per outing, supporting their attacking work.

Looking further into the data, St Pauli have lost 50% of their last 22 matches in all competitions and have been winless in 12 out of their last 15 Bundesliga games. They have also lost six of their past 12 home league matches, highlighting ongoing struggles at Millerntor-Stadion. In 13 of their last 15 home games in the Bundesliga, they have failed to claim all three points.

RB Leipzig’s recent trends read much more favorably. They've emerged victorious in 12 of their last 20 games across competitions. They remain undefeated in 13 of their last 16 overall, and have a tendency to rack up significant wins: 39% of their last 28 matches have been won by at least two goals. On the road, they have kept a clean sheet in 42% of their past 12 away fixtures.
previewText:
The Bundesliga clash at Millerntor-Stadion pits St Pauli against RB Leipzig in a fixture where form and firepower come sharply into focus. As the home side strive to lift themselves from the bottom half of the table, Leipzig arrive as clear favorites, boasting one of the league's most potent attacks.

St Pauli's record in their last two home encounters against RB Leipzig offers a glimmer of encouragement. Across these matches, St Pauli have managed one win and one draw, notably avoiding defeat and demonstrating resilience on their own turf. However, history outside these two games points strongly in Leipzig's favor, with the visitors winning two out of the last three meetings and both of those victories by a margin of two or more goals.

St Pauli approach this fixture with mixed recent results. In their last six matches, they've claimed two wins, drawn twice and lost two times, while averaging just one goal for and 1.17 conceded per match. Their offensive output at home has been slight, with an average of only 0.67 goals scored across the last three matches at Millerntor-Stadion, conceding two per game in the same period.

Leipzig, meanwhile, show signs of consistency and firepower. Over their previous six matches, they've taken three wins, a single draw, and two defeats, with an impressive average of 2.17 goals scored per outing and only 1.17 conceded. The visitors generate plenty of chances, leading with an average of 16.83 total shots and 7.33 on target per game in this span. Notably, their away form features five wins from their last ten on the road in all competitions.

St Pauli's league position underscores their uphill challenge. After 15 matches, they sit 16th, with just three wins, three draws, and nine defeats, struggling with a negative goal difference of -13 and an average of only 0.87 goals per game. Defensively, they've allowed 1.73 goals per match, underlining the issues at both ends.

Leipzig, on the other hand, are entrenched in the top four after 15 matches. They boast nine wins, two draws, and four losses, with a healthy goal return of 30 (an even two per game) and a positive goal differential of +11. Their defense allows just 1.27 goals per outing, supporting their attacking work.

Looking further into the data, St Pauli have lost 50% of their last 22 matches in all competitions and have been winless in 12 out of their last 15 Bundesliga games. They have also lost six of their past 12 home league matches, highlighting ongoing struggles at Millerntor-Stadion. In 13 of their last 15 home games in the Bundesliga, they have failed to claim all three points.

RB Leipzig’s recent trends read much more favorably. They've emerged victorious in 12 of their last 20 games across competitions. They remain undefeated in 13 of their last 16 overall, and have a tendency to rack up significant wins: 39% of their last 28 matches have been won by at least two goals. On the road, they have kept a clean sheet in 42% of their past 12 away fixtures.

previewParagraphs: The Bundesliga resumes at Europa-Park Stadion as Freiburg prepares to host Hamburger SV. With both teams aiming to improve their mid-table positions, recent data strongly points toward a compelling encounter.

Freiburg enters this fixture with a favorable historical record against Hamburger SV, having won 3, drawn 2, and lost 1 in their last 6 meetings. This positive trend will surely give Julian Schuster’s side a boost.

Recent league form also tilts the scales toward Freiburg. Over their last 6 matches, they have secured 4 wins, 1 draw, and suffered just 1 defeat. With an average of 2.17 goals scored and only 1 conceded per match, Freiburg’s balance between attack and defense has been a key driver this season.

Home performances have been especially impressive. Across their last 3 matches at Europa-Park Stadion, Freiburg are unbeaten with 2 wins and 1 draw, conceding just 0.33 goals per game while producing an average of 20 total shots and dominated possession at 56%.

Much of this consistency stems from a stable lineup and tactical flexibility. Expect Freiburg to line up in their familiar 4-2-3-1 formation. Based on recent selections and squad health, the likely starting eleven should be:
Midfielders: Maximilian Eggestein, Patrick Osterhage, Philipp Treu, Yuito Suzuki, Johan Manzambi

Hamburger SV, on the other hand, come into this game in the midst of a patchy run. In their last 6 outings, Merlin Polzin’s team has won just twice, drawing 2 and losing 2 while averaging 1.17 goals scored and 1.5 conceded per match. Their struggles are even more pronounced on the road, where they’ve lost all of their last 3 away games, managed only 0.67 goals and conceded a worrying average of 3 per match.

Examining the trends over a larger sample, Hamburger SV have found it difficult to get results away from home. They have failed to win in 83% of their last 12 away matches across all competitions and suffered losses in 6 of those games. Additionally, they have lost by 2 or more goals in 43% of their last 7 away fixtures, reflecting ongoing defensive vulnerabilities.
The likely formation for Hamburger SV is the 3-4-3 they’ve favored recently, and their probable starting lineup looks like this:
Midfielders: Bakery Jatta, Albert Sambi Lokonga, Nicolai Remberg, Aboubaka Soumahoro

Considering league position after 15 matches, Freiburg sit 9th, boasting 5 wins, 5 draws, and 5 losses, with a nearly even goal difference. Hamburger SV are 13th, with 4 wins, 4 draws, and 7 losses while carrying a minus-9 goal differential. These standings reflect broader season trends, with Freiburg generally outperforming their guests.

In longer-term trends, Freiburg have collected 16 wins from their last 30 matches in all competitions and managed to remain undefeated in 24 of those fixtures. The home side has kept clean sheets in 40% of their last 10 Bundesliga home games and won by a margin of 2 or more goals in 40% of those as well.

The predictive model supports a Freiburg win at 42% probability, suggesting the home team’s solid form at Europa-Park Stadion could once again prove decisive. The algorithm forecasts a 3-1 result, aligning with Freiburg’s steady attacking output and Hamburger SV’s ongoing defensive frailties.

Overall, the metrics heavily favor Freiburg, whose consistent performances and reliable home record provide the foundation for a likely victory against a Hamburger SV side still seeking answers on their away travels.

previewParagraphs: Manchester City vs Exeter City: Form lines point toward a one-sided FA Cup 3rd Round, but margins still matter

Cup ties have a way of compressing narratives into ninety minutes, yet the numbers behind Manchester City and Exeter City sketch a clear story about control, territory and shot quality. This preview pulls apart the form lines, trends and likely lineups to frame what each side must overcome.

Manchester City arrive on a sturdy platform. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions they have 3 wins, 3 draws and 0 losses, averaging 1.5 goals scored and only 0.5 conceded. They are carrying the ball for long spells too, with 63% average possession and 16.33 total shots per match, 5.5 of those on target.

At home, City’s last 3 in all competitions read 1 win, 2 draws and 0 losses, with 1.67 goals scored and 0.67 conceded, underpinned by 17.67 total shots and 61.33% possession. The platform is there even if the finishing edge has been slightly muted.

Exeter City’s last 6 in all competitions show 3 wins, 1 draw and 2 losses, producing 1.33 goals for and 0.83 against. Their attack has generated 10.67 shots per match and 4.33 on target on a leaner 45.83% possession share. The baseline is competitive, but they typically play without the ball for long spells.

City’s recent FA Cup body of work is formidable. In the league-specific trends, they have won 85% of their last 40 FA Cup matches and haven’t been defeated in 34 of those last 40. Margin control is notable too, with wins by 2 or more goals in 63% of their last 30 FA Cup games.

Exeter’s own FA Cup markers show resilience: they have 7 wins in their last 12 FA Cup matches and haven’t been defeated in 6 of their last 7 in the competition. That said, stepping away from competition-only data, their away profile in all competitions is a concern, as outlined below.

Zooming out to all competitions, Manchester City’s long arc remains elite. They have 27 wins across their last 40 matches, are undefeated in 11 straight, yet are also on a run of 3 consecutive draws, which explains the recent dip in cutting edge. At home, they have been formidable with 26 unbeaten in their last 30 and 73% wins across their last 15.

Exeter’s broader picture is mixed. Over the last 15 matches in all competitions they have 8 wins, but across 34 matches they have 17 losses. Away from home is the biggest red flag: they have lost 65% of their last 20 away matches and are winless in 6 of their last 7 away in all competitions.

City’s tendency to control matches is backed by clean-sheet capability at home, keeping 42% clean sheets across their last 12 in all competitions and winning by 2 or more in 65% of their last 20 home games. Their recent streaks underline both security and slight stalling in attack: undefeated in 11, but winless in 3 due to consecutive draws.

Exeter’s cup resilience is real, yet travel remains their swing factor. They are winless in 6 of their last 7 away matches in all competitions, and that typically intersects poorly with City’s possession and chance volume at the Etihad.
